judge.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the official in control of a court, who decides how criminals should be punished
judge.translation[0].definitions[0].note: federal judge/high court judge etc (=a judge in a particular court)
judge.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The trial judge specifies the number of years to be spent in prison.
judge.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: someone who decides on the result of a competition
judge.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The panel of judges included several well-known writers.
judge.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to form or give an opinion about someone or something after thinking carefully about all the information you know about them
judge.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: You should never judge a person by their looks.
Judge us on the improvements we make in the economy.
The therapist judged that Margaret had made a serious attempt to kill herself.
pollutants that were judged hazardous to human health
I am in no position to judge whether what she is doing is right or wrong.
The economic results of the reforms are very difficult to judge.
The likelihood of future bombs was impossible to judge.
We judge the success of a product by the number of sales it brings in.
His conduct, judged objectively  by what he has done, is dishonest.
Robert wanted to go and help him, but judged it best to stay where he was.
Do not judge her too harshly, as she was very young at the time.
judge.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to decide on the result of a competition
judge.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: I had the difficult task of judging the competition.
Competitors will be judged on speed and accuracy.
judge.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to form an opinion about someone, especially in an unfair or criticizing way
judge.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: He just accepts people for what they are and he doesn’t judge them.
judge.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to decide whether someone is guilty of a crime in court
judge.translation[1].note_box[0].section: be difficult/hard to judge
The economic results of the reforms are difficult to judge.
be impossible to judge
How much this affected their children was impossible to judge.
judge something objectively
His behaviour, judged objectively by what he has done, is dishonest.
judge somebody harshly
Do not judge her too harshly; she was very young at the time.
judge something correctly
It takes a lot of experience to judge correctly what is needed.
judge something a success/failure
The concert was judged a success.
judge something on its merits
The arguments should be judged on their merits.
judge something on the basis of something
It is difficult to judge progress on the basis of a single day.
judge it best/better to do something
Robert wanted to go and help him, but judged it best to stay where he was.
judge it safe to do something
He listened for some time before judging it safe to go downstairs.
judge.translation[1].note_box[1].section: to form an opinion about someone or something, using your knowledge, experience, and intelligence
He will judge whether the project has been a success.
It’s difficult to judge how long the work will take.
assess
to judge how good, bad, successful etc someone or something is, especially by using a fixed set of standards. Assess is often used about measuring students’ abilities and performance
Are tests and exams the best way to assess students’ progress?
The insurance company will send someone to assess the damage.
evaluate
to judge how good, bad, successful etc someone or something is, especially by carefully examining all the information about them. Evaluate is often used about the work of people doing research
The data from the study is still being evaluated.
The test is used to evaluate the effects of pesticides on domestic bees.
gauge
to judge people’s opinions or feelings about something, or to measure the effect, importance etc of something. Gauge is often used when talking about getting a general idea of what something is like
A meeting was arranged in order to gauge the opinions of pupils, parents and teachers.
It' s too early to gauge the impact of the oil price rises on people’s spending.
Without further information it is impossible to gauge the full extent of the problem.
appraise
to judge how successful, effective etc someone or something is, especially by comparing their good and bad points
Twice a year, managers appraise the performance of employees.
This research aims to appraise the effectiveness of different kinds of public sector financial assistance.
On what basis will a teacher be appraised?
judge.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the official in control of a court who decides how criminals should be punished, or makes decisions about disagreements that the court has been asked to solve
judge.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The case is scheduled for trial today before Judge Robert Parker.
judge.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to form or give an opinion about how good or bad something is
judge.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The company will be judged on its quarterly reports.
Analysts’ recommendations are judged against a performance index for the industry they follow.
